A Montessori Approach to Learning Language

Stacy Keane, MONTESSORI TEACHER + PARENT

Ages
2-3,
3-4
Critical Thinking
Language + Literacy

Learn the Montessori approach to learning language and how to apply it every day.

Learn

Basic Concepts

Montessori is an educational approach based on the teachings and observations of Dr. Maria Montessori. It is a unique method that values the development of the whole child (e.g., physical, social, emotional and cognitive), and encourages a thoughtfully prepared learning environment to support self-directed learning. A Montessori approach to learning language implies some key concepts:

  • The Absorbent Mind is hard at work.
    • Young children unconsciously absorb everything in their environment without bias, including intangible aspects like the language that surrounds them.
      • Being intentional about a child’s surroundings can have a profound impact on their learning.
    • Infants and preschoolers have exponential learning periods that help guide their Absorbent Mind to internalize specific aspects of their environment, such as movement, routine and language.
      • For example, around age two, many children experience a growth spurt in language use. This is because, in part, they have spent much of their first two years of life absorbing language around them.
  • Sensorial experiences deepen meaning.
    • Exposure to real objects and experiences surrounding language deepens the meaning a child attaches to a particular word and allows them to recognize it in other contexts.
      • For example, if a child hears the word ‘pineapple’, they will have a deeper connection to the word if they also taste it, touch it or read about it in a book.
      • For this reason, memorization without context does not provide a full understanding of the underlying meaning.
    • The Montessori method believes a child must learn what is before thinking about what could be.
      • A strong foundation in reality – knowing what is true – is helpful for when a child matures and learns to think and write imaginatively about what could be.
    • Real materials teach children to respect materials, beauty and process.
      • When a child knows they can independently do real things with real materials, it builds their growing confidence to write and speak.
      • When a child is engaged in purposeful life activities, it enhances their interest in learning.
  • The brain can encode (write) before it can decode (read).
    • Children are ready to write before they are ready to read.
    • First offer opportunities for writing; then offer opportunities for reading.
      • It is important to give a young child the tools they need to write on their own before they learn to read another person’s writing. This is easier to do because writing is the creation of one’s own thoughts rather than attempting to decipher another person’s thoughts.
  • Learning is a unique process.
    • Every child develops and learns at their own pace.
    • Learning in context and incorporating learning into daily routines is most effective.

Do

Apply a Montessori Approach to Your Daily Routine

(PRINT ME!)

What You Could Do
The Absorbent Mind is hard at work
  • Offer a variety of rich experiences for your child to absorb. For example:
    • Rotate thought-provoking hanging artwork like picture cards.
    • Intentionally arrange learning materials so that they are organized and easy to access.
    • Keep objects in classified groups; this can help promote early counting skills.
    • Create an open floor playing space that invites discovery and choice.
    • Play with toys and materials that use many senses (like a ramp racer).
  • Talk, talk, talk! – Experiment with words and model conversation from birth.
    • Back-and-forth interactions are critical for language learning.
    • Oral language development and storytelling leads to literacy development.
    • Talk numbers!
  • Look for print in context – Point out letters and words on road signs and product packaging, and involve your child in pointing them out daily.
Sensorial experiences deepen meaning
  • Play with real materials or replicas. For example:
    • Create a basket of animal action figures or miniature vehicles.
    • Use a ceramic tea set.
    • Create a basket of real fruit so that your child can explore with their multiple senses the meaning of ‘fruit’. What does it feel, smell, look, and taste like?
  • Play with abstract concepts using concrete challenges (like pop blocs or a trinomial cube).
  • Integrate sound awareness into your daily routines. Play sound games whenever you can. For example:
    • “I hear the sound b in banana; b-b-b banana.”
    • “I hear the sound t at the end of cart.”
    • After some practice, you could add, “What other words start with b?”
The brain can encode (write) before it can decode (read)
  • Practice writing at home using multiple senses. For example:
    • Use a salt tray.
    • Use sandpaper letters and numbers.
  • Read *with* your child – Developing a lifelong love of reading is as important as learning how to read.
    • The connected experience of being with your child will promote a positive association throughout their life.
  • The goal is to encourage and fuel your child’s desire to write and speak with confidence. Avoid trying to correct mistakes at the early stages of learning to write and speak.

More Montessori resources for language development HERE.

More questions about the Montessori approach? Ask us!

Stacy Keane, MONTESSORI TEACHER + PARENT

Stacy is a recognized Association Montessori Internationale (AMI) teacher with a Masters in Education from Loyola University. She has almost 15 years experience teaching young learners at Forest Bluff School in Lake Bluff, IL. She contributes extensively to the curriculum and coaching platform at Monti Kids. She is also a busy parent to three young children.

Bérénice Saint-Saëns, Teacher

Bérénice is a recognized Association Montessori Internationale (AMI) teacher with a Masters in Education from Loyola University. Bérénice currently manages the partnerships and affiliate program at Monti Kids, as well as expertly coaches families on how to implement the Montessori learning philosophy at home.
